column2: Potential Indirect (Enablers or Proxies) Corelating Data Points
Potential Indirect Corelating Data Points (Proxy Variables for Financial Inclussion)

column3: Positive (↑ Device Access → ↑ Use of Digital Finance)
column4: The on‑ramp to DFS; Findex 2025 and sector studies consistently tie connectivity to usage.

column2: Affordability of data (cost of 2GB as % GNI)
column4: High data costs depress DFS adoption and sustained use; affordability gaps are steep across Africa.
Persistent gender gaps flag structural constraints (ID, phone, norms) and require tailored design; Ethiopia exhibits deep gaps.

column2: Agent Network Density (agents per 10k adults + agent activity rate)
column4: For low‑income and rural areas, agents are the interface of financial inclusion, cash‑in/out, registration, customer support. Weak agent networks = low digital usage.
Dense or semi‑dense economic zones have better network coverage, more merchants, more agent points, and more economic activity, driving faster DF adoption.
Captures effective connectivity, not just network availability.
Measures supply-side readiness for high-quality digital services.
Low literacy constrains onboarding, product understanding, and consumer protection, increasing reliance on assisted or agent-based models.
Shows the population’s ability to use digital tools safely and independently.
Links digital adoption to income flows and use cases.
A non-negotiable infrastructure input for digital inclusion.

column2: Average hours of power outages per month
column4: Captures quality of electricity supply, not just access. Frequent outages undermine service reliability, merchant acceptance, and consumer trust in digital channels.

column2: Rural population with mobile internet access (%)

column4: Indicates advanced digital usage and ecosystem growth.
Enables scalable, low-cost onboarding and KYC.

column2: Government payments digitized (% of G2P flows)
column4: Digitized G2P payments drive account usage and serve as an entry point for first-time users.
